Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Digitization TCN: Mobilizing New England Vascular Plant Specimen Data to Track Environmental Changes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Herbarium specimens provide a source of historical information useful to the study of global environmental change. The goal of this project is to provide data to support studies of the nature and consequences of environmental change in the New England region over the last three centuries. This project will digitally capture specimen data and images from about 1.3 million vascular plant specimens from herbaria across New England, enhancing the data with georeferencing, habitat, and phonological information. The digitization process will integrate with existing community efforts and will develop novel high-throughput digitization technologies to increase efficiency and decrease costs. All resulting data and images will be freely available on-line.

The data from this project will be of immediate use to scientists who study climate and land-use change, and will provide a better understanding of how global changes will impact the distribution of native and introduced plant species. This project will benefit research in taxonomy, ecology, morphology, biogeography, and evolutionary history by making available data on an entire regional flora in an electronic format. The methodologies developed will provide a model for other regions around the nation. In addition the project will utilize citizen scientists, school groups, and students providing training, research, and educational opportunities. . This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Outcomes

 

The goal of this project was to digitize the New England specimens of the New England herbaria, and make the specimens and the label data available on-line.  One particular task for me in this project was to advise the group of systems of that could be used to classify the different stages of development of plant reproduction and leafing phenology. This data would make the specimens more valuable in ecological, evolutionary, and climate change research. A second goal of my part of the work was to develop new approaches to making herbarium specimens more valuable in ecological, evolutionary, and climate change studies. A third task was to assist in digitizing the Boston University herbarium, which is now done.

 

The work from this project is now complete, and all of the studies are now published or are in review.  Here are the studies and their significance. 

 

Everill, P. H., R.B. Primack, E.E. Ellwood, and E.K. Melaas. 2014. Determining past leaf-out times of New England’s deciduous forests from herbarium specimens. American Journal of Botany101: 1-8. 

 

This study demonstrates that it is possible to determine leafing out times of trees from herbarium studies, greatly extending out knowledge of tree leafing out time into the past. The main result is that trees are now leafing out earlier than in the past, with implications for ecosystem processes.

 

Willis, C.G., E.R. Ellwood,R.B. Primack, C.C. Davis,K.D. Pearson, A.S. Gallinat,J.M. Yost,G. Nelson,S.J. Mazer,N.L. Rossington,T.H. Sparks,P.S. Soltis. 2017. Old Plants, New Tricks: Phenological Research Using Herbarium Specimens. Trends in Ecology and Evolution32: 531-546.

 

In this paper, we describe the opportunities and limitations of using herbarium specimens in climate change research, emphasizing the tremendous new opportunities provided by the millions of herbarium specimens recently available on-line. 

 

Daru, B.H., D.S. Park, R.B.Primack, C.G. Willis,D.S. Barrington, T.J.S. Whitfeld,,T.G. Seidler, P.W. Sweeney, D.R. Foster, A.M. Ellison, C.C. Davis. 2017. Widespread sampling biases in herbaria revealed from large-scale digitization. New Phytologist, doi: 10.1111/nph.14855.

 

In this study, we demonstrate that herbarium specimens have strong biases that must be considered in ecological and climate change studies. For example, specimens are often collected near universities and museums, and some species are over-collected or under-collected. Research studies that do not consider these biases may get flawed results. 

 

Pearse, W.D., C.C. Davis, D. Inouye, R.B. Primack, and T.J. Davies. 2017. Measuring the limits of phenology: estimating synchrony and variation in contemporary, historic, and citizen-science datasets. Nature Ecology and Evolution 1: 1876–1882.

 

One of the challenges of phenology research is combining field observations of first flowering with dates of peak flowering from herbarium specimens.  In this paper, we develop and demonstrate a statistical technique that allows first flowering to be estimated from herbarium specimens, allowing diverse data sets to combined in ecological and climate change research. 

 

Gallinat AS, EK Melaas, CG Willis, RB Primack. 2018. Investigating fruit ripening times for native and invasive plant species across New England using herbarium specimens. American Journal of Botany, doi: 10.1002/ajb2.1005

 

This study utilizes herbarium specimens to demonstrate that there are strong differences among species in fruiting times, that fruiting times are not obviously changing over time, and that non-native invasive species generally fruit later in the autumn than native species. Further field work is needed to determine how this affects the feeding behavior of migratory bird species. 

 

Ellwood, ER, RB Primack, CG Willis, and J HilleRisLambers. 2018. Phenology models using herbarium specimens are only slightly improved by using finer-scale stages of reproduction.  Applications in Plant Sciences, in review. 

 

This study addresses the question of the optimum number of phenological categories for classifying plant reproduction and plant leafing times.  The answer depends on finding the balance between the effort needed to collect the data and the increasing power of the analysis.  Our results demonstrate that simple systems of classification provide almost the same results as more detailed systems, and are probably to be preferred in citizen science projects.

 

While this project is now complete, we are following up this project with additional studies. The most notable study involves using herbarium specimens to confirm the observations of fruiting times of 70 bird-dispersed We expect this project to be complete in early 2019.

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2018
Modified by: Richard B Primack
